author: By Eve Sampson
title: A Timeline of Some of the Deadliest Attacks in Ukraine’s War With Russia
description: At least 11,520 civilians had been killed in the war, according to a United Nations report in July, which said the true tally may be higher.
content: The Russian missile strike Tuesday on a military academy and nearby hospital in eastern Ukraine, which killed more than 50 people, was one of the deadliest attacks since Moscow’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Dudding
title: James Darren, Actor, Singer and ‘Gidget’ Heartthrob, Dies at 88
description: His role as a surfer in that trendsetting hit movie led to success on television shows like “The Time Tunnel” and “T.J. Hooker,” and on the pop charts.
content: James Darren, an actor and singer whose starring role as a California surfer in the “Gidget” movies made him one of the most popular heartthrobs of the late 1950s and early ’60s, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: The Power Broker at 50
description: Robert Caro’s hugely influential book still resonates with politicians and public officials in New York City today.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at “The Power Broker” by Robert Caro, which has its 50th anniversary this month, and hear what it means to New York officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: How an Ohio Town Landed in the Middle of the Immigration Debate
description: Jobs attracted thousands of Haitians to Springfield, and employers were ecstatic. But then an immigrant driver was involved in a fatal school bus crash. And JD Vance entered the fray.
content: It has been more than a year since the fateful morning last August when, outside Springfield in southwestern Ohio, a minivan veered into oncoming traffic and rammed into a school bus on the first day of class, killing an 11-year-old boy and injuring 23 other children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Tatiana Firsova
title: Former Volkswagen Chief Executive Faces Trial in Emissions Case
description: Nine years after the carmaker admitted to concealing emissions on a massive scale, Martin Winterkorn will be tried in a German court.
content: Almost nine years after Volkswagen admitted that it had rigged millions of cars to cheat on emissions tests, the company’s former chief executive went on trial Tuesday on charges stemming from the fraud, a vast corporate conspiracy that changed the auto industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier, Sanjana Varghese and Malachy Browne
title: Dozens Die in Congo Jailbreak Attempt After Stampede and Gunfire
description: Inmates at the overcrowded Makala prison had sought to escape their suffocating cells after water and power went out. At least 129 were killed, some two dozen of them shot dead, the government said.
content: At least 129 people died during an attempted jailbreak at the largest prison in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the country’s authorities said on Tuesday. It was the latest upheaval to hit an overcrowded detention facility notorious for conditions that human rights groups have long decried as inhumane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Chicago Man Charged in Fatal Shootings of Four Sleeping Train Passengers
description: “This was a random act of violence,” an official said. The man, 30, faces four counts of murder.
content: A 30-year-old Chicago man has been charged with murder in the deaths of four passengers who were fatally shot on Monday as they slept on an L train in the suburb of Forest Park, Ill., the authorities said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Meaney
title: Germany Before the Nazis: A Democracy That Didn’t Need to Fail
description: The Weimar Republic was a hotbed of cultural experimentation. A new history argues that its demise was not inevitable.
content: For nearly a century, the Weimar Republic has served as the West’s compact mirror, pundits compulsively checking it for ominous signs of resemblance. Is society more polarized? Is the press increasingly in the hands of bombastic billionaires? Do monopolists seem eager to work with demagogues to protect their interests? Are new technologies threatening to make the world unrecognizable? Weimar Germany, those 14 fateful years between the Kaiserreich’s defeat in World War I and Hitler’s ascent to power, has something for everyone, a bountiful supply of déjà vu and I-told-you-so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: How Netanyahu Is Trying to Save Himself, Elect Trump and Defeat Harris
description: The Israeli prime minister’s approach to Gaza and the hostages is plainly tied up in his political self-interest.
content: If President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris needed any reminder that Benjamin Netanyahu is not their friend, not America’s friend and, most shamefully, not the friend of the Israeli hostages in Gaza, the murder by Hamas of six Israeli souls while Netanyahu dragged out negotiations should make that clear. Netanyahu has one interest: his own immediate political survival, even if it undermines Israel’s long-term survival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: 23 New Restaurants to Try This Fall
description: The season’s marquee openings in New York City include the next move from Kent Hospitality, the first Manhattan restaurant from Andrew Tarlow and more.
content: It’s a season of contrasts. At some New York City restaurants, tables are being set — get this — with white linen, while kitchens are lighting rustic wood fires. Menus are leaning toward dry-aged fish and Italian food, both red-sauce and ancient-grain esoteric. There’s an array of Korean choices; steaks and seafood at Park Avenue prices; and plats du jour in intimate townhouses and bustling brasseries. Marquee chefs — Daniel Boulud, Michael White, Alex Stupak — keep muscling in, and there are promising newcomers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: Texas Deputy Is Shot to Death on His Way to Work
description: A deputy constable was driving to work Tuesday when he was shot and killed at an intersection in Houston, the police said. A suspect was in custody Tuesday afternoon.
content: A deputy constable in Houston was killed on his way to work early Tuesday afternoon when a man walked up to his car at an intersection, shot the deputy multiple times and fled, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Back to School
description: How do you feel about the start of a new academic year?
content: Maybe your school started back in mid-August, or maybe you’re just returning to the classroom this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Activists Charged With Pushing Russian Propaganda Go on Trial in Florida
description: Experts say the case offers a window into how the Russian government tries to influence American elections and promote its own geopolitical agenda.
content: An unusual trial that began on Tuesday in Tampa, Fla., involves obscure candidates for local office, activist groups far outside the political mainstream and relatively little money changing hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Elon Musk’s Starlink Agrees to Block the X Social Network in Brazil
description: Brazilian regulators had said Sunday that Starlink planned to defy government orders to block X in the country. On Tuesday, the satellite-internet service said it would comply.
content: Starlink, the satellite-internet service controlled by Elon Musk, reversed course on Tuesday and said it would comply with Brazilian government orders to block Mr. Musk’s social network X in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Hewlett Packard to Pursue $4 Billion Claim Against Mike Lynch’s Estate
description: The money is tied to a lawsuit in Britain by the tech services giant over its acquisition of Autonomy, the software firm Mr. Lynch founded. He died last month.
content: Hewlett Packard Enterprise will continue to pursue civil fraud damages of up to $4 billion from the estate of Mike Lynch, the British software mogul who died last month when his yacht sank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Russia’s Attack on Poltava Comes After a Week of Strikes in Ukraine
description: Moscow appears to have stepped up the tempo of its attacks, resulting in a wave of death and destruction in Ukraine.
content: The Russian missile strike that killed more than 40 people in the eastern city of Poltava on Tuesday comes after a difficult few days for Ukraine, in which Moscow appears to have stepped up the tempo of its attacks, resulting in a wave of death and destruction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: A U.K. Succession Drama: Who Will Be the Next Ambassador to the U.S.?
description: Diplomat Karen Pierce has built alliances with Trump officials and the Biden-Harris administration. But with her term set to end next year, the U.K. government has a dilemma over her replacement.
content: In the hectic four-and-a-half years she has served as Britain’s ambassador to the United States, Karen Pierce has overseen a costly renovation of her baronial Washington residence and confronted an American political system in comparable need of repair. The house, at least, is finished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
title: Why It’s So Hard for China to Fix Its Ailing Economy
description: A real estate collapse has made consumers cautious and businesses wary, as China confronts a crisis unlike any other since it opened its economy to the world.
content: In 2004, as China’s economy was emerging as a global force, a group of researchers started conducting nationwide surveys asking Chinese people if they were better off financially than they were five years earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘The Notebook’ Will End Its Broadway Run in December. A Tour Is Next.
description: The show, nominated for three Tony Awards, opened March 14 at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater. It will go on a national tour starting next September.
content: “The Notebook,” a musical adapted from the best-selling novel by Nicholas Sparks, will end its Broadway run on Dec. 15 after struggling to find sufficient ticket buyers during a competitive spring and summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Liubov Sholudko and Ephrat Livni
title: Scenes of Carnage After Russian Attack on Ukrainian Military Academy and Hospital
description: The devastation of the strikes on Tuesday was shocking even to Ukrainians who have seen many such scenes during the war.
content: Rescue workers from the State Emergency Service were already on the scene, desperately searching for survivors, when Denys Kliap arrived. They were pulling bodies from the rubble “without legs, others without arms, some even without heads,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Protests and work stoppages in Israel.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel rebuffed calls from allies, protesters and the families of hostages for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza that would facilitate the return of hostages, doubling down on his refusal to agree to a truce that would involve Israel’s withdrawal from the territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Jimmy Gitaka
title: An Olympic Runner From Uganda Is Severely Burned in Gasoline Attack
description: Rebecca Cheptegei, a long-distance runner who competed in the Olympic marathon in Paris, is in critical condition after a man poured gas on her and set her on fire, police in Kenya said.
content: A Ugandan long-distance runner who competed at the Paris Olympics this summer has been severely burned in Kenya, after a man who was in a relationship with her poured gasoline on her and set her on fire on Sunday, according to the local authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: An Incomplete List of Everything Threatening China’s National Security
description: Watch out for Good Samaritans with ulterior motives, packages in your mail and college students looking to make a quick buck, China tells its people.
content: What do snapping turtles, tissue boxes and college students looking for part-time jobs have in common?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: In ‘Lovely One,’ Ketanji Brown Jackson Credits the Mentors Who Lifted Her Up
description: The Supreme Court justice’s memoir is deeply personal and full of hope, and highlights a fairy-tale marriage to her college boyfriend.
content: Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson handed down many important decisions on her way to becoming the first Black woman appointed to the nation’s highest court in 2022. But perhaps the most astute was rejecting a career in the magazine industry before anyone could see it was dying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Toxic Additive Found in Feed That Killed 70 Oklahoma Rodeo Horses
description: Preliminary tests show that the feed had been contaminated with Monensin, an additive known to be toxic to horses, Livestock Nutrition Center said.
content: The company that supplied the feed that fatally poisoned at least 70 horses at a legacy breeding ranch in Oklahoma last month has confirmed that the shipment had been contaminated with an additive known to be toxic to horses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman
title: A Trump Clemency Recipient Is Convicted of Domestic Violence
description: A man whose life sentence for his role in a robbery and murder was commuted by President Donald J. Trump was convicted this spring of a misdemeanor charge of assaulting his wife.
content: A man whose life sentence in federal prison was commuted in 2021 by President Donald J. Trump was convicted this spring of a misdemeanor charge of assaulting his wife, the latest example of a Trump clemency beneficiary getting in legal trouble again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Ease Into Fall With 7 Songs for September
description: Listen to tracks inspired by this month of transitions and memories from Green Day, Barry White, Fiona Apple and more.
content: In previous installments of this newsletter, I’ve compiled collections of songs about specific months, like June and August. But we’re now entering one that has a particular and persistent hold on the musical imagination (sing it with me now): Sep-tem-ber. This definitely calls for a playlist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsey Graham
title: Lindsey Graham: How Trump Can Improve His Chances of Winning
description: The former president can win by talking up his successes.
content: With a little more than two months to go until Election Day, it’s fair to ask if Donald Trump can win in November. The presidential race is virtually tied in all the major swing states. Last month’s Democratic National Convention was both a hate fest directed squarely at our former president and a fawning coronation of Vice President Kamala Harris, the nominee who didn’t win a single primary in 2020 or 2024. Every day that the candidates trade insults is a good day for her because it’s one less day that she has to defend the failures of the Biden-Harris administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Soltis Anderson
title: Don’t Flip Out Over Election Forecasts
description: Election forecasters and their predictive models in the presidential race are in the spotlight. Here’s how to understand this work better.
content: We are now past Labor Day and in the homestretch of the 2024 campaign, and a lot of people are asking me and others in political polling and media: Who’s going to win in November? Is the race Donald Trump’s to lose? Can Kamala Harris turn her momentum into victory?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Ex-Doctor Pleads Guilty to Manslaughter in New York Woman’s Suicide
description: Stephen Miller, a right-to-die advocate, was sentenced to five years’ probation. His lawyer said that “morally” Mr. Miller had done nothing wrong.
content: A former doctor from Arizona pleaded guilty to manslaughter on Tuesday and was sentenced to five years’ probation after admitting that he had helped a 59-year-old woman kill herself in a motel room in the Hudson Valley in New York last fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Ugandan Opposition Leader Bobi Wine Shot in Leg in Clash With Police
description: Mr. Wine, a pop star turned politician who ran for president, is in the hospital, but his injuries are not life-threatening, one of his lawyers said.
content: Uganda’s top opposition figure, Bobi Wine, was shot in the leg by the police on Tuesday, his political party said, calling it an escalation of a government campaign of intimidation against a prominent critic who challenged the country’s autocratic leader in a run for the presidency in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Surprise! A Class of College Seniors Learns Tuition Will Be Free.
description: Tuition used to be free for all students at the Cooper Union, in New York City. The school announced it was bringing back the perk, at least for seniors.
content: The first day of the semester at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art in New York on Tuesday came with a surprise for seniors that will make them the envy of college students everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Tom Mashberg
title: Collector Sues to Block Investigators From Seizing Roman Bronze
description: Lawyers for the collector, based in California, said the Manhattan district attorney’s office did not have the jurisdiction or the evidence to support seizing the ancient statue.
content: A California collector has gone to court to block efforts by New York investigators to seize an ancient Roman bronze statue that they assert was looted from Turkey in the 1960s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in September
description: A glitzy mystery starring Nicole Kidman arrives early this month; later, a new true-crime series tells the troubling tale of Lyle and Erik Menendez.
content: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of September’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Cathay Pacific Finds 15 Planes Need Engine Repairs
description: The Hong Kong airline has canceled dozens of flights to inspect Airbus A350 planes since it found a problem with a Rolls-Royce engine in one of them.
content: Hong Kong’s flagship airline, Cathay Pacific, said on Tuesday that it had found that 15 of its Airbus A350 planes required repair after an engine component failed on a plane headed to Zurich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: His Parents Are Susan Sarandon and Tim Robbins. That’s the Joke.
description: In a series of videos, Jack Robbins has been lampooning nepo baby culture — and embracing it — with help from his parents and Steven Spielberg’s daughter.
content: For Jack Henry Robbins, the day begins with stretching and meditation, followed by two to three seconds of tooth brushing. After visiting his favorite neighborhood coffee shop, a Nespresso boutique on the Upper East Side, he returns home to begin work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: 100 Easy Dinners for Right Now
description: Meal planning can be a slog. Let us help.
content: Summer is hot dogs and ice pops, shaggy dinners at dusk, the melting mixture of energy and malaise that gives the season its shape. But that’s not fall. Fall is crisp. Fall is orderly. There’s no malaise and no melt. Those anything-goes August dinners give way to meal plans sketched out on Sunday and empty lunchboxes waiting to be filled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Arlette Bashizi, Valerie Hopkins, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Netanyahu Unwavering on Cease-Fire, and Putin Visits Mongolia
description: Plus, battling mpox in Congo.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Guttenfelder, Yurii Shyvala, Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora
title: No Time to Run: Russian Missiles Hit Ukraine City Just After Sirens Sound
description: More than 50 people were killed by two high-speed missiles that hit a military academy in the eastern city of Poltava, one of the most lethal Russian strikes in the war.
content: Russian missiles struck a military academy in eastern Ukraine on Tuesday only minutes after air-raid alarms blared, killing more than 50 people, wounding many others and underscoring Moscow’s superior firepower in one of the war’s deadliest attacks. Ukraine’s president said a hospital also was hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: The Spies of ‘Slow Horses’ Are ‘as Useless as Everyone Else’
description: Will Smith, the showrunner, discusses the comic spy thriller, which returns for its fourth season on Wednesday and is up for nine Emmy Awards later this month.
content: The British spies at the center of the Apple TV+ series “Slow Horses” aren’t particularly handsome, or efficient, or disciplined. They’re rejects from MI5, consigned to a dark, dingy London office run by Jackson Lamb (Gary Oldman), a slovenly, scotch-swilling, flatulent burnout. Early in Season 4, which premieres Wednesday, Lamb objects when a new no-nonsense MI5 officer (Ruth Bradley) handcuffs him during an investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Two U.S. Marines Attacked in Turkey by Nationalist Youth Group
description: Turkish officials said they had detained 15 members of the group. The two servicemen had returned to the ship and were safe, U.S. officials said.
content: The Turkish authorities said they had detained 15 members of a nationalist youth organization in connection with the assault of two U.S. Marines stationed in a port city in western Turkey on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Ukraine Electric Company Boss Fired as Russia Pounds Power Grid
description: The head of Ukrenergo was reportedly blamed for failing to fortify energy infrastructure, which has come under steady Russian bombardment, leading to blackouts.
content: The head of Ukraine’s electric company was fired on Monday, the utility said, just a week after a major Russian aerial attack on the power grid caused blackouts in Kyiv and other cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Harris’s Operation Will Put $24.5 Million Toward Down-Ballot Democrats
description: She is sending $10 million each to the House and Senate Democratic campaign arms, and another few million to help elect Democratic governors, state legislators and attorneys general.
content: The fund-raising apparatus of Vice President Kamala Harris will direct $24.5 million to organizations dedicated to electing down-ballot Democratic candidates, Ms. Harris’s campaign chief said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Alvin Ailey, the Man and the Mind Behind the Unapologetic Sparkle
description: In “Edges of Ailey,” a new exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art, the choreographer takes center stage. It’s another revelation.
content: The name Ailey is synonymous with dance. Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is more than a company: It’s a brand, an integral piece of the cultural fabric of this country. It’s huge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Emma Bubola
title: Pope Visits Indonesia, Where Muslim-Christian Harmony Is Under Strain
description: Indonesia is proud of its religious diversity and its reputation for tolerance, but minorities, including Catholics, still face discrimination.
content: The hallelujahs rang out on Sunday from a small hall on the outskirts of Jakarta, the capital of Indonesia. The sounds from the Christian service could be heard within the green and orange mosque across the way, as a group of young girls in hijabs walked by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Home Cooking So Good, Only a Restaurant Could Do It
description: In her first review as interim critic, Melissa Clark visits Lola’s, whose produce-driven cooking is familiar but lifted by brilliant twists and tweaks.
content: This is Melissa Clark’s first review as an interim restaurant critic, along with Priya Krishna, for The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson and Tiffany Hsu
title: Left-Wing Misinformation Is Having a Moment
description: America’s right flank remains the chief purveyor of misinformation, but this summer’s political tumult created ideal conditions for falsehoods to spread among progressives.
content: Several elected officials, along with a top political aide for the billionaire Reid Hoffman, recently suggested, without proof, that former President Donald J. Trump may have staged an attempt to assassinate him in July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Judge Denies Trump’s Request to Move Criminal Case to Federal Court
description: Judge Alvin Hellerstein said the Supreme Court’s finding that presidents enjoy immunity does not apply in the hush-money case in which Donald Trump was already convicted.
content: A federal judge in Manhattan denied an effort by Donald J. Trump to move his already adjudicated state criminal case to the federal courts on Tuesday, rejecting his claims of presidential immunity and brushing aside his allegation of bias.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Migrants in N.Y. Shelters Face Surprising Challenge: Getting Their Mail
description: Mail delivery has become a complicated endeavor at hotels and other places converted into shelters, with important documents getting lost or delayed.
content: With 64,000 migrants shuttling through a warren of shelters in New York City, one of the city’s more difficult challenges is among the more unheralded: delivering the mail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: The Best Time to Get a Flu Shot
description: There is such a thing as getting a vaccine too soon. Here’s what to know.
content: In the waning days of summer, flu season can still feel a long way off. Yet some pharmacy chains have already started urging consumers to beat the crowds and schedule a flu vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Kaufman
title: How NAFTA Broke American Politics
description: Since its passage in 1993, the trade agreement has played an outsize role in presidential elections — which now often hinge on the three Rust Belt states it helped to hollow out.
content: In May of last year, Marcus Carli, the plant manager of the Master Lock factory in Milwaukee, Wis., called a surprise meeting with the board of United Auto Workers Local 469. Several officers of the union, which represents the workers at the plant, joined Carli and an executive from Master Lock’s parent company in a tiny conference room. Carli brought along a security guard. “He’s here for my protection,” Carli told the union representatives. As the guard sat down, Yolanda Nathan, the local’s incoming president, noticed his gun. “That’s when I thought, Oh, we’re losing our jobs,” she says. Carli immediately confirmed her worst fears. “The plant’s closing,” he announced. “It took my breath away,” Nathan says. “It took all our breaths away.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: A Heat Pump Can Cut Your Emissions. But Read This Before You Switch.
description: A Times climate reporter recounts his journey to switch his home’s HVAC system to a climate-friendly heat pump.
content: You’ve probably heard the pitch for heat pumps: They can cut greenhouse gas emissions by more than half compared with traditional gas-powered HVAC systems. They’ll save you money because you’ll pay less for energy. And, thanks to the tax credits passed by Congress in 2022, they’re more affordable than ever. What’s not to love?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korean Teenagers Detained Over Deepfake Sexual Images
description: The country has been hit by a wave of sexually explicit videos and pictures that have spread online, prompting the authorities to launch a sweeping investigation.
content: The authorities in South Korea are investigating a surge of sexually explicit images and video clips that have spread online and shocked the nation, leading the police to detain seven male suspects — six of them teenagers — the police said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Carville
title: James Carville: Kamala Harris’s Best Strategy to Defeat Trump
description: She has to help Trump hurt himself in the debate, break with Biden on policy and show how she has grown since the 2020 campaign.
content: I hate to say it, but Donald Trump remains the singular most recognized name in the United States. Since he moseyed down that golden escalator in 2015, he has dominated the American airwaves and algorithms. Whether they hate him or love him, people know exactly what Mr. Trump’s shtick is.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: India’s Exhausted Medical Workers Are Fearing for Their Safety
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 3, 2024.
content: “They are either seen as supra-human, or not human at all.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Upper Hand
description: Alex Eaton-Salners crosses the floor.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Leichter
title: To Survive in the Future, Humanity May Need to Become Less Human
description: In Hiromi Kawakami’s new science fiction novel, Earth is a place of surveillance, isolation and dread. The characters (and clones) are doing their best to stay alive.
content: People are produced in factories. Communities exist in isolation, spread out from one another by design. Children are raised by groups of mothers, a network of caretakers who may not be altogether human. One narrator seems closer to vegetable than animal. A man can project his mind onto the brain of a bird, but the technology for space travel is long lost. Earth is a place of dread, and humanity might be done for. The problem, summarized by one character: “how to preserve even a slim chance that we might someday thrive on this planet again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: When Property Investors Want Out, These Bargain Hunters Rush In
description: Investment firms are raising record sums for real estate secondary funds that cut private deals to buy assets from investors who can’t otherwise exit.
content: Investors in private real estate funds have a problem: Even as the prices of office buildings and other commercial properties tumble, their holdings are locked up, possibly for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Son of John McCain Says Trump Team’s Cemetery Clash Violated ‘Sacred Place’
description: Jimmy McCain said the confrontation at Arlington National Cemetery could be “extremely triggering” for the families of U.S. service members buried there.
content: Jimmy McCain, a son of the Vietnam War P.O.W. and longtime Republican senator John McCain, said Tuesday that the campaign of former President Donald J. Trump had committed a “violation of a sacred place” when it clashed with an official at Arlington National Cemetery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: benign
description: This word has appeared in 181 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word benign has appeared in 181 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 10 in “What’s in Store for the 2024 Hurricane Season?” by Christopher Kuo:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Justice Jackson Treads Carefully in Talking About the Supreme Court
description: By contrast, the first Black woman on the Supreme Court was more forthcoming in her memoir about her upbringing in Miami, Matt Damon and her rise to the court.
content: As soon as Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson was permitted to speak out publicly under Supreme Court tradition, she delivered the keynote address from the pulpit of the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala. It was September 2023, the 60th anniversary of the Ku Klux Klan bombing that killed four young Black girls as they arrived for Sunday morning services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Brian Stelter Returns to CNN as Chief Media Analyst
description: Mr. Stelter, who left CNN two years ago, will be helming his newsletter for the network, but without a Sunday show.
content: CNN’s “Reliable Sources” is back. Kind of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Daniel Craig Gets Explicit (and Romantic) in Luca Guadagnino’s ‘Queer’
description: At the Venice Film Festival, the star said he embraced the scenes with sexual encounters: ‘If I wasn’t in the movie and saw this movie, I’d want to be in it.’
content: If you know Daniel Craig only as James Bond, “Queer” is liable to throw you for a loop. In this new film from Luca Guadagnino, which premiered at the Venice Film Festival on Tuesday, Craig, 56, plays a drug addict whose sexual escapades and heroin use are filmed with matter-of-fact candor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Political Rage of Left-Behind Regions
description: What we can learn from the geography of right-wing extremism.
content: There were local elections in several German states a few days ago, and the results — a strong showing by the Alternative for Germany or AfD, a right-wing extremist party — were shocking but not surprising. Shocking because, given their history, Germans more than anyone else should fear the rise of anti-democratic right-wing forces. Not surprising because the AfD has been rising for a while, especially in the former East Germany, where the elections were held.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By River Akira Davis
title: Kamala Harris Says U.S. Steel Should Stay American-Owned
description: Both major presidential candidates now say they oppose the proposed takeover of the industrial giant by Nippon Steel of Japan.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris said U.S. Steel should stay in the hands of American owners, dealing another blow to the Japanese manufacturer Nippon Steel’s $15 billion proposal to acquire the storied American steel maker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Russia Carried Out One of the Deadliest Strikes of the War
description: Also, polio vaccinations in Gaza are beating goals. Here's the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Two Russian missiles hit a military academy today in Poltava, a city in eastern Ukraine, killing more than 50 people and injuring scores of others, Ukrainian officials said. Ukraine’s president said a hospital had also been hit. It was one of the most lethal attacks of the two-and-a-half-year war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcelle Hopkins
title: Seeing Dances of the Harlem Renaissance, in Vivid Color
description: An immersive article spotlights choreographers who are carrying forward the legacy of Black dance forms that flourished 100 years ago.
content: There’s a scene in Toni Morrison’s novel “Jazz,” the 1992 work of historical fiction set in the Harlem Renaissance, in which young musicians play a tune on a rooftop in Harlem. As the music floats down to Lenox Avenue, people stop in their tracks to appreciate the sound emanating from above.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Slain Hostages, and the Aftermath
description: Readers react to Biden, Netanyahu and the killing of the hostages. Also: Trump and I.V.F.; a gay-Christian alliance; reasons for joy; Disney trips; fancy dorms.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: Stocks Slump and Oil Prices Slide as Unease Returns to Markets
description: The S&P 500 fell more than 2 percent on Tuesday, its biggest single-day drop since an early August meltdown.
content: A sharp decline in major stock indexes on Tuesday ruptured a weekslong rebound on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 falling by the most in nearly a month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Cuomo to Testify to Congress on Nursing Home Deaths During Pandemic
description: The former New York governor, who has already testified behind closed doors to the Republican-led House panel investigating the coronavirus pandemic, has agreed to appear on Sept. 10.
content: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has agreed to testify publicly next week before a congressional subcommittee to face questions about the thousands of deaths that occurred in the state’s nursing homes during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Five Favorite Dinners From Our New Weeknight 100
description: Spiced roast chicken with yogurt sauce, dumpling noodle soup and mustard-lemon salmon are here for you when life gets busy (a.k.a. fall).
content: Labor Day has come and gone, and we are back at school and back to the grind here at Five Weeknight Dishes. I’m always here with dinner recipes for busy people (that’s you). But in honor of September and the transition to new schedules and routines that comes with the shifting of the seasons, I’ve made a fresh list of 100 recipes for you to try in the months ahead: the Weeknight 100, if you will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Harris, Proposing a Tax Break, Makes a Play for Small-Business Owners
description: The plan, which Kamala Harris will announce on Wednesday in New Hampshire, would allow new companies to deduct up to $50,000 in start-up expenses, a campaign official said.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris on Wednesday is set to propose expanding a tax break for start-ups, one of a series of policy ideas her campaign is rolling out this week aimed at helping entrepreneurs and small businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren
title: Can Democrats Stop the ‘Tax Doom Loop’?
description: Democrats are tired of losing to Republicans on tax policy. They’re hoping to mount a comeback next year.
content: For more than two decades, Democrats have watched with frustration as tax policy in the United States has settled into a pattern, one that Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Massachusetts Democrat, calls the “tax doom loop.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Hwaida Saad
title: Ex-Head of Lebanon Central Bank, Under Investigation in Corruption Cases, Is Detained
description: Riad Salameh, once seen as an international financial wizard, is the subject of multiple inquiries and has attracted blame for the country’s economic crisis.
content: The longtime former governor of Lebanon’s central bank was detained on Tuesday after being questioned by Lebanese authorities, said the country’s general prosecutor, Judge Jamal Hajjar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Natasha Singer, Sydney Harper, Carlos Prieto, Luke Vander Ploeg, Nina Feldman, Marc Georges, Brendan Klinkenberg, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: The Push to Ban Phones in School
description: A growing number of states are cracking down on students’ use of the devices.
content: As students around the United States head back to school, many are encountering a new reality: bans on their use of cellphones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman, Ronen Bergman and Glenn Thrush
title: U.S. Charges Hamas Leaders in Oct. 7 Massacre in Israel and Other Terrorist Attacks
description: Yahya Sinwar, the group’s political chief, was charged with carrying out the attacks that resulted in the killing of at least 43 Americans. Five other Hamas senior leaders were also charged.
content: Federal prosecutors charged Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, and five senior members of the group with planning and carrying out years of terrorist attacks in Israel, including the Oct. 7 massacre, according to a sweeping complaint unsealed on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: The Dream Was a House on the Russian River (on a Budget)
description: Getting there required buying something far worse than the typical fixer-upper: “It was like excavating in Pompeii.”
content: There are so many reasons to want a little house on the Russian River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Rethinking Addiction as a Chronic Brain Disease
description: Some researchers argue that the roles of social environment and personal choice have to be considered in order to make progress in treating people addicted to drugs.
content: The message emblazoned on a walkway window at the airport in Burlington, Vt., is a startling departure from the usual tourism posters and welcome banners:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jia Tolentino
description: The Sep. 3, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jia Tolentino. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘A Drunk Dial Followed by Sporadic G-Chats ’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: It was 2007, and after three months of dating, Mike’s dinner declaration was a crushing blow for me: “Serena, the most I can commit to is a casual relationship.” A drunk dial followed by sporadic G-chats kept us in touch, but his Dubai move seemed like a sign to move on. Yet our chats intensified, becoming near daily. A spontaneous Barcelona meet-up — seven months after he dumped me and our last face-to-face — changed everything. Fast forward to 2024: married with three children and living in New York City, the very place he swore he’d left behind. — Serena Bhaduri
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Fungus That’s Transforming Charcuterie and Cocktails
description: Plus: a new sleeper carriage on the Venice Simplon-Orient-Express, men in capes and more from T’s cultural compendium.
content: Koji, the mold that transforms soy beans and wheat into soy sauce and rice into sake, is so beloved in Japan that it has its own holiday. And lately, chefs have been finding new uses for the fungus, which has a fruity aroma and an ability to make “anything it touches better,” says Jeremy Umansky, 41, the owner of Larder deli in Cleveland. He uses koji for almost everything: to cure pastrami; to ferment Chinese-style black beans, which are ground and swirled into chocolate babka to embolden the chocolate; and to sprinkle over salads and fries in the form of what the restaurant calls Special K, a seasoning of dried ground koji. “It’s a harmonizer,” he says. Bartenders, too, are taking note. At Nancy’s Hustle in Houston, the bar manager, Zach Hornberger, 32, adds it to the nonalcoholic Silver Brining cocktail, a sweet-sour-salty mix of pickle brine, grapefruit and lime juices, koji and tonic. “It brings this umami background to beverages, and it plays well with citrus, taming the high acid notes and rounding the drink as a whole,” he says. At the restaurant Fête in Honolulu, the bar manager, Fabrice McCarthy, 41, infuses rum with shio koji (a slurry of koji, water and salt) and shakes it into a mai tai to add salinity — the effect, he says, is similar to how salted peanuts make you want to drink more beer. Ryan Chetiyawardana, 40, the owner of the bar Lyaness in London, experiments with koji in multiple forms — for one cocktail, he ferments parsnips with koji, which he says unlocks the sweetness and delivers “a huge tropical brightness.” While koji often plays a supporting role, at Paradiso in Barcelona, it wraps around the entire lip of the glass used for the Fleming, named for Alexander Fleming, the discoverer of penicillin, another influential mold. For this fungus-inspired cocktail, which includes grapefruit, tequila and miso, the manager of Paradiso’s research lab, Matteo Ciarpaglini, 30, one-upped a classic salt rim with a fluffy cloud of koji, its floral fragrance accompanying every taste. — Martha Cheng
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: What if Orchestras Were More Like Netflix?
description: As subscriptions face an uncertain future, classical music could look to the membership models of streaming services and gyms for inspiration.
content: Perhaps you spend your mornings at the gym, working out with the help of a playlist on Spotify. In the evening, you wind down with Netflix or a movie on Max. As you go to bed, you might even open a meditation app to help you fall asleep. Then you wake up, and do it all again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and William K. Rashbaum
title: N.Y. Official Charged With Taking Money, Travel and Poultry to Aid China
description: Linda Sun, who worked for both Gov. Kathy Hochul and Gov. Andrew Cuomo, was accused of using her position to benefit the Chinese government.
content: In July 2021, six Nanjing-style salted ducks, prepared by a Chinese consulate official’s private chef, were delivered to the parents of an aide to New York’s then governor, Andrew M. Cuomo. About four months later, another six ducks arrived at their home. Another four months later, there were more salted ducks. Eight months after that: still more salted ducks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Supreme Court Rejects Oklahoma’s Bid for Federal Grants in Dispute Over Abortion Counseling
description: Oklahoma asked the justices to weigh in after a lower federal court ruled the state was not entitled to millions of dollars in federal family-planning grants after it refused to refer patients to a national pregnancy hotline.
content: The Supreme Court on Tuesday turned down a request from Oklahoma to restore millions in federal family-planning grants that the Biden administration withheld after the state announced that it would no longer provide access to abortion counseling services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Tell Us: How Are You Feeling About the Debate?
description: Share your thoughts with the On Politics newsletter.
content: The presidential debate on Sept. 10 will be the first time that former President Donald Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris face off onstage. And it could be the most important moment of the fall campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig
title: Plea Deal Resolves Remaining Charges in Killings of Albuquerque Muslim Men
description: The defendant, Muhammad Syed, pleaded no contest to two murder charges. But his motive remains unknown.
content: The prosecution of a New Mexico man charged in a string of killings that shook Albuquerque’s Muslim community moved toward a conclusion on Tuesday, even as questions about his motive appeared likely to remain unanswered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: As Israel’s Rifts Widen, Netanyahu Remains Defiant
description: In strikes and protests, many Israelis are pushing their government to prioritize the release of hostages above the immediate defeat of Hamas. But Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has refused to change course.
content: When Israel’s largest union began a strike on Monday, building on the largest anti-government protests since the start of the war in Gaza, the group hoped to persuade the government to swiftly agree to a cease-fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: The Stakes on Taxes
description: We cover the presidential candidates’ positions on taxation.
content: Today, we are starting a series called The Stakes covering the major issues of the campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Wednesday Briefing: Russian Strike Kills 50 in Ukraine
description: Plus, a quiz to test healthy brain habits.
content: Two high-speed Russian missiles struck Poltava, a city in eastern Ukraine, killing more than 50 people and wounding scores more. It was one of the deadliest attacks in the war and followed a string of Russian assaults across Ukraine that started last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Lozada-Oliva
title: An Overdose Forces a Hard Look at a Family History of Addiction
description: In Coco Mellors’s second novel, “Blue Sisters,” three adult siblings reunite on the first anniversary of their sister’s death.
content: “A sister is not a friend.” So begins Coco Mellors’s sophomore novel, “Blue Sisters,” whose three adult protagonists are in a constant fight — with one another, with their various addictions, with their own worst selves. For Mellors, it’s these fights that define sisterhood, as “tough, sinuous, unlovely, yet essential” as an umbilical cord: “You’re part of each other, right from the start.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Healy and Vishakha Darbha
title: These Young Voters Offer a Road Map for Kamala Harris
description: Listen in on this focus group with undecided Gen Z voters.
content: Listen in on this focus group with young undecided voters — a group that could determine the outcome of the upcoming presidential election. The New York Times deputy Opinion editor, Patrick Healy, spoke with some Gen Z voters to better understand the issues they’re focused on and how they’re feeling about Donald Trump and Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Las Vegas, Scorched by Its Hottest Summer on Record, Sees More 100-Degree Heat This Week
description: Much of the Western U.S. will bake in high temperatures this week. Excessive-heat warnings have been issued for major cities including Las Vegas and Los Angeles.
content: Pumpkin-spice lattes will be best served iced this week in the Southwest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: Shiny New Technology, Same Old Funny Business
description: Antitrust regulators are finally catching up to the methods used by modern corporations to exert their power.
content: Illegal price fixing used to require a lot of work. In the mid-1990s, to fix the price of the animal feed additive lysine, executives of some of the world’s biggest agribusinesses had to spend hours on airplanes flying to resorts where they spent days in conference rooms determining how much lysine each company could sell, and at what price.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Britain Awards 10 Contracts for Offshore Wind Projects
description: The successful outcome of the government auction for renewable energy projects may bolster a wind industry battered by rising costs.
content: The British government on Tuesday awarded price support contracts for a series of offshore wind farms as part of a wider package for renewable energy, a reversal from a disappointing auction last year in which there were no takers for offshore wind projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Vance Championed 2017 Report on Families From Architects of Project 2025
description: JD Vance, as he was dipping his toe into politics, praised the Heritage Foundation report — 29 essays opposing abortion and seeking to instruct Americans on how to raise children — as “admirable.”
content: Years before he became the Republican vice-presidential nominee, JD Vance endorsed a little-noticed 2017 report by the Heritage Foundation that proposed a sweeping conservative agenda to restrict sexual and reproductive freedoms and remake American families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump Ordered to Stop Using Isaac Hayes Song at Rallies
description: A federal court judge in Georgia granted a request by the singer’s estate to bar the former president from playing “Hold On, I’m Coming” at his events.
content: A federal judge on Tuesday ordered former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign to stop using the song “Hold On, I’m Coming,” by Isaac Hayes, at campaign events in response to a lawsuit from the artist’s estate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Putin Gets a Red-Carpet Welcome in Mongolia Despite Arrest Warrant
description: Ukrainian officials expressed outrage over the Russian leader’s visit, warning they would seek to “ensure that this has consequences” for Mongolia.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was warmly received by the leader of Mongolia on Tuesday in his first state visit to a member nation of the International Criminal Court since it issued a warrant for his arrest last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden and Megan Specia
title: At Least 12 Die Trying to Cross English Channel, French Officials Say
description: Over 60 people were crowded into a small boat that “rapidly and brutally” broke apart off the coast of France, authorities said.
content: At least 12 people, including what appeared to be six minors, died after a flimsy, overcrowded boat suddenly capsized off the coast of northern France on Tuesday during an attempt to cross the English Channel, the French authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: A Hostage Deal Is a Poison Pill for Israel
description: Captives should not be ransomed at the cost of creating more hostages.
content: Since the days of Abraham — who, according to Genesis, rescued his nephew Lot after he’d been seized by an invading army — Jewish tradition has placed supreme value on the redemption of captives. It is, in a sense, the fulfillment of a primary, implicit commandment: to be one’s brother’s keeper. It is also a source of Jewish communal cohesion over millenniums to never forsake those who have been taken, even if only to give them a proper burial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Will the College Protests Matter in November?
description: Republicans tied campus unrest to their party platform. But the intensity may have fizzled.
content: Good evening! College students are returning to campus, and with them comes the potential for new campus protests. Alan Blinder, who covers higher education for The Times, takes a look at a big question that could shape the weeks between now and Election Day. — Jess Bidgood
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What Song Was the Soundtrack of Your Summer?
description: If you had to choose a tune to describe your summer vacation, what would it be, and why?
content: The end of summer is approaching, and that means music fans’ favorite unwinnable debate is reaching its peak: What was the song of the summer?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Montgomery
title: Creating an Artistic Buzz, One Real Estate Development at a Time
description: Artwork has been part of urban projects for decades, but a new push from developers looking for ways to drive foot traffic has created a boom for the art world.
content: On Kilroy Realty’s website, the developer declares that it “has a love affair with great art.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Christmas Starts in October, Venezuela’s Autocrat Declares
description: With the nation’s democracy in shambles, President Nicolás Maduro tries to inject some holiday cheer.
content: A nationwide blackout. A broken economy. A widely contested presidential election. A populace terrified of its autocratic leader and his increasingly violent security forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: From School Librarian to Activist: ‘The Hate Level and the Vitriol Is Unreal’
description: Amid a surge in book bans nationwide, the librarian Amanda Jones was targeted by vicious threats. So she decided to fight back.
content: One Sunday morning two years ago, Amanda Jones, a middle school librarian in Watson, La., woke up and saw an email on her phone that left her shaking and breathless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: New Photos From Titanic Show Long-Lost Statue and Damaged Bow
description: RMS Titanic Inc., the company that led the expedition, brought back two million photos of the site. The ship’s famed bow has been damaged, the company said.
content: In its first expedition to the Titanic in 14 years, the company with exclusive salvage rights to the wreckage site said it had located a bronze statue thought to have been lost forever, and it also discovered some deterioration of the ship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump Aides Evacuated Offices After Prank Sparked Bugging Fears
description: The police were called after suspicious devices were found at a Florida campaign office. It was quickly determined that the devices were likely part of a prank.
content: Watergate this was not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 451
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Sept. 4, 2024.
content: Introducing Connections Bot: a daily tool that provides a personalized analysis of your Connections solve, inspired by WordleBot. Connections Bot lets you know the puzzle’s difficulty level, and whether you made the same mistakes as other solvers. The bot is now available exclusively to the Connections Companion community. Give it a try and let us know your thoughts in the comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden’s Top Climate Negotiator to Visit China This Week
description: John Podesta is expected to push for China to set more ambitious greenhouse gas targets.
content: John Podesta, President Biden’s top climate diplomat, is traveling to Beijing on Tuesday where he is expected to press Chinese leaders to make more ambitious plans to cut the greenhouse gas emissions that are driving climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: On Children, Meaning, Media and Psychedelics
description: The writer Jia Tolentino on parenting — and living a good life — in the age of smartphones.
content: I feel that there’s something important missing in our debate over screen time and kids — and even screen time and adults. In the realm of kids and teenagers, there’s so much focus on what studies show or don’t show: How does screen time affect school grades and behavior? Does it carry an increased risk of anxiety or depression?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Sabrina Carpenter Beats Travis Scott to No. 1 by a Hair
description: The pop singer and songwriter’s “Short n’ Sweet” debuts atop the Billboard 200 with the equivalent of 362,000, the third-best opening of the year.
content: In an extraordinarily close contest on this week’s Billboard album chart that left the music industry biting its collective nails with anticipation over the holiday weekend, the pop singer Sabrina Carpenter triumphed over the veteran rapper Travis Scott to clinch the No. 1 spot — but just barely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rita Koganzon
title: An Infantilizing Double Standard for American College Students
description: It’s time for students to take back their independence.
content: Picture two 20-year-olds. One is a full-time college student and the other is a full-time waiter. Both go out one night to drink and have a good time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Why Silicon Valley Is Abuzz Over ‘Founder Mode’
description: A debate is brewing among investors and entrepreneurs: Are hands-on founders, such as Steve Jobs and Brian Chesky of Airbnb, the key to start-up success?
content: Silicon Valley has been abuzz in recent days over one topic in particular: How hands-on should founders be in their companies? In the framing of Brian Chesky, the Airbnb co-founder and C.E.O., and Paul Graham, the Y Combinator co-founder, it comes down to “founder mode” versus “manager mode.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennie Erin Smith
title: In Colombia, You Can Watch Whales, and Serenade Them, Too
description: Every year, as thousands of humpbacks return to their breeding grounds near a protected bay, locals gather on the beach to greet them with stories, dancing and music.
content: Every July, tens of thousands of visitors descend on Colombia’s Pacific Coast, crowding the frenzied passenger docks in the seaport of Buenaventura as they wait for speedboats that will whisk them to the small communities lining remote Málaga Bay. They’ve come to see the humpback whales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: You Just Got a Tattoo. How Do You Look After It?
description: Advice on tattoo aftercare is plentiful, and sometimes confusing. Tattoo artists and dermatologists weigh in on what you should do.
content: The new tattoo may be of an unfurling script, a bold geometric sleeve or a funny illustration. Perhaps it is your first, or joins a medley: inked in honor of a person, place or the spirit of self-expression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,173
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, September 4, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ephrat Livni
title: Dozens of Hostages Remain in Gaza: What We Know
description: More than 60 living hostages, and the bodies of about 35 others taken captive on Oct. 7, are still in Gaza, the Israeli authorities say.
content: Protests and labor strikes erupted across Israel after the military said on Sunday that it had recovered the bodies of six hostages from Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Sabrina Carpenter and Pop’s Next Gen Have a Secret Weapon: Amy Allen
description: The songwriter behind the summer smashes “Espresso” and “Please Please Please” is helping drive a moment of idiosyncrasy in Top 40 hits.
content: Some well-played profanity can make a pop song sizzle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. and Iraqi Commandos Targeted ISIS in Sprawling Operation
description: The number of insurgent attacks has increased, officials say, as Iraq and the United States negotiate a plan to wind down the U.S.-led military mission.
content: American and Iraqi commandos raided several Islamic State hide-outs in western Iraq last week, killing at least 14 ISIS fighters in one of the most sweeping counterterrorism missions in the country in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: 11-Year-Old Is Charged in Killing of 82-Year-Old Ex-Mayor and His Daughter
description: The police said that the boy had confessed to fatally shooting two relatives: a former mayor of the small city of Minden, La., and his 31-year-old daughter.
content: An 11-year-old boy is facing murder charges after he confessed to fatally shooting an 82-year-old relative who had once served as mayor of a small Louisiana city and the man’s adult daughter over the weekend, the police said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton and Vladimir Karaj
title: Trump Family’s Land Deals in Albania Stir Up Lingering Resentments
description: Local landowners are questioning how Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump were able to sew up development rights for two luxury hotels on hot coastal property.
content: Two luxury real-estate projects in Albania proposed by the son-in-law of former President Donald J. Trump are stirring up lingering tensions in that country, with the Trump family facing accusations that land it hopes to develop has been improperly set aside for them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz and Mike Isaac
title: OpenAI, Still Haunted by Its Chaotic Past, Is Trying to Grow Up
description: The maker of ChatGPT is struggling to transform itself into a profit-driven company while satisfying worries about the safety of artificial intelligence.
content: OpenAI, the often troubled standard-bearer of the tech industry’s push into artificial intelligence, is making substantial changes to its management team, and even how it is organized, as it courts investments from some of the wealthiest companies in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Election 2024 Polls: Biden vs. Trump (Archived)
description: Our polling averages of the Biden vs. Trump matchup in the 2024 presidential race, using data from national and battleground state polls.
content: Our polling averages of the Biden vs. Trump matchup in the 2024 presidential race, using data from national and battleground state polls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: Quiz: Do You Have Healthy Brain Habits?
description: These 12 questions can help assess your risk for dementia, stroke and depression, and identify ways to reduce it.
content: These 12 questions can help assess your risk for dementia, stroke and depression, and identify ways to reduce it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Massachusetts 4th Congressional District Primary Election Results
description: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Massachusetts primary election.
content: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Massachusetts primary election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Can You Find the 12 Thrillers Hidden Within This Text?
description: The 20th-century Cold War was rife with geopolitical tension and inspired a lot of great espionage thrillers. This text puzzle challenges you to uncover the titles of a dozen novels set in and around that frosty era.
